fullText: Kelli O'Hara and Ken Watanabe bring fresh depth and nuance to the classic Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, making this revival feel both timeless and urgently contemporary.
dtliExcerpt: Kelli O'Hara and Ken Watanabe bring fresh depth and nuance to the classic Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, making this revival feel both timeless and urgently contemporary.
bwwExcerpt: There are moments in Lincoln Center Theater's ravishing new Broadway production of The King and I (***Â½ out of four) that may leave you grinning so hard your face will hurt. Then suddenly, without warning, you'll be fighting off tears...The one element missing from this new revival is a rock-solid leading man. Making his Broadway debut as the King of Siam, Japanese film star Ken Watanabe doesn't yet hold the stage with complete confidence, or enunciate all of his lines clearly. But his performance is brave, underlining the character's hidden vulnerability, and at times disarmingly playful. Sparring with and teasing Anna, his King can convey an almost childlike sense of mischief, and wonder. O'Hara complements and supports her co-star with a study in effortless poise, singing and acting with gorgeous subtlety. There is nothing forced or strident about this Anna; when she stands up to the King -- defying his attitudes about women, and his apparent need to demean his subjects -- her indignation is made more powerful by her sustained grace.
showScoreExcerpt: Kelli O'Hara and Ken Watanabe bring fresh depth and nuance to the classic Rodgers and Hammerstein musical, making this revival feel both timeless and urgently contemporary.
